page.title: Adverbial Clauses
page.introduction: This section considers the complements that can follow temporal and reason adverbs. Temporal adverbs with complements are used here to illustrate the constructions, then both types will be dealt with for your language on the next screen.

EnglishExample.exItem: English examples of temporal adverbs with complements used in full sentences include:
John has been home [since last week].
[Since John has been home from the hospital] he is doing better.
John is feeling fine [now that he is home from the hospital].
The dog followed Sue everywhere [when she returned from college].
[When she returned from college], the dog followed Sue everywhere.

page.introduction:
These examples show that particular temporal adverbs subcategorize for certain types of complements. In example 1 since is followed by another temporal adverb, in example 2 by a temporal nominal phrase, and in example 3 it has a sentential complement. Examples 5 and 6 show that when also takes a sentential complement, whereas now in example 4 has a CP complement.
All of these adverbial clauses (or phrases) act the same as simple temporal adverbs, so they will be temporal AdvPs with the appropriate type of complement. Note also that adverbs of this type normally may occur either sentence-initial or sentence-final.
